decision: Do any of the following apply to your device
information: A ‘nanomaterial’ means a natural, incidental or manufactured material containing particles in an unbound state or as an aggregate or as an agglomerate and where, for 50% or more of the particles in the number size distribution, one or more external dimensions is in the size range 1-100 nm; Fullerenes, graphene flakes and single-wall carbon nanotubes with one or more external dimensions below 1 nm shall also be deemed to be nanomaterials according to MDR, Article 2(18). Examples of devices with nanomaterials include and intravascular catheter made of non-degradable polymer with nano-coating and dental filling materials.
hint: Examples of devices intended for recording of X-ray diagnostic images are X-ray films or a digital X-ray detectors for recording images, and not an X-ray machine itself.

options.when: The device is intended for recording X-Ray diagnostic images
The device utilizes non-viable human or animal tissues, cells or their derivatives
The device is intended specifically to be used for disinfecting or sterilizing medical devices
None of these apply to my device

decision: (a). Is the device intended to come into contact with intact skin only?

options.when: Yes
No

decision: (b). Does the use of nanomaterials result in
information: The high, medium, low or negligible potential of internal exposure is based on the combination of different factors such as the application site of a medical device, type of contact (e.g. tissue, cells or body fluids), contact time and the type of incorporation of the nanomaterial(s) (free, fixed, embedded). When the nanomaterial is applied as coating on the surface of the device, it is important to consider the type of interaction with the material (chemisorption versus physisorption). When the nanomaterial is embedded in a matrix it will be important to consider the degradability of the material.
hint: Here are some examples with devices that fall into each of the described risk level - a bone filler with nanomaterials in its formulation presents a high or medium potential for internal exposure; bone fixation screws/plates with a strongly bound nano-coating present a low potential for internal exposure; and, dental fillers present a negligible potential for internal exposure.

options.when: Negligible potential for internal exposure
Low potential for internal exposure
High or medium potential for internal exposure

decision: Do any of the following apply to your device?
information: A body orifice is an natural opening in the body, as well as the external surface of the eyeball, or any permanent artificial opening, such as a stoma.
hint: Administration of medicinal product by inhalation refers to inhalation of the medicine into the respiratory system. For example, spacers intended for metered dose inhalers and oxygen delivery systems with nasal cannulas.

options.when: It is invasive via body orifices (not surgically invasive) to administer medicinal product by inhalation
It is composed of substances to be introduced into the body via a body orifice or applied to the skin and absorbed by or locally dispersed in the body
None of these apply to my device

decision: (a).  Does your device’s mode of action have an essential impact on the efficacy and safety of the administered medicinal product AND/OR the is the device intended to treat life-threatening conditions?

options.when: Yes
No

decision: D(b). Do any of the following apply to your device?

options.when: The substances are applied to the skin, the nasal or oral cavity as far as the pharynx and achieves their intended purpose on those cavities
The substances are systematically absorbed by the human body in order to achieve the intended purpose
The substances achieve their intended purpose in the stomach or lower gastrointestinal tract and are systematically absorbed by the human body
None of these apply to my device

decision: Is your device an active therapeutic device with an integrated or incorporated diagnostic function, which significantly determines the patient management by the device?
information: An active therapeutic device is any active device used, whether alone or in combination with other devices, to support, modify, replace or restore biological functions or structures with a view to treatment or alleviation of an illness, injury or disability. Examples of devices that fall under this question are closed loop systems or automated external defibrillators.
hint: Additional questions related to other types of active devices (i.e., rules 9 to 13 in the MDR) appear later in this questionnaire.

options.when: Yes
No

decision: Is your device intended to be invasive?
information: Invasive: Any device which, in whole or in part, penetrates inside the body, either through a body orifice or through the surface of the body. A device that administers energy to the body should not be considered as invasive if the only energy it emits penetrates the body and not the device itself.
hint: If your device only comes into contact with injured skin or mucous membrane, please select "no" to this question.

options.when: Yes
No

decision: (a). Is the device intended to be invasive in a body orifice or stoma or is it intended to be surgically invasive?
information: Surgically invasive: an invasive device which penetrates the body through the surface of the body, including through mucous membranes of body orifices with the aid or in the context of a surgical operation; and a device which produces penetration other than through a body orifice. The term surgical operation includes all clinical interventional procedures in which a device is placed into the body through the surface of the body. A surgically invasive device always implies that it enters through an artificially created opening.
hint:
A surgically created stoma used in urostomy, colostomy and ileostomy or permanent tracheostomy is considered to be a body orifice; therefore devices introduced into such a stoma are not surgically invasive. In contrast, a surgically created opening to allow access to the circulatory system should not be considered to be a body orifice. Devices introduced into such an opening are surgically invasive.

Examples of devices that are invasive via body orifices are corrective contact lenses, tracheal tubes, urethral stents and examination gloves (not surgical gloves). The surgically invasive definition can also apply to certain devices used in dental surgery, such as dental alloys or ceramics.

options.when: Invasive in a body orifice or stoma
Surgically invasive

decision: (b). What is the duration of use?

options.when: Transient use - continuous use for less than 60 minutes
Short term use - continuous use for between 60 minutes and 30 days
Long term use - continuous use for more than 30 days

No

decision: (g). Which of the following applies to your device?
information: Reusable surgical instrument: An instrument intended for surgical use in cutting, drilling, sawing, scratching, scraping, clamping, retracting, clipping or similar procedures, without a connection to an active device and which is intended by the manufacturer to be reused after appropriate procedures such as cleaning, disinfection and sterilization have been carried out.

options.when: It is a reusable surgical instrument
It is intended to administer medicines in a potentially hazardous manner
It is intended to supply energy/ionizing radiation
It has a biological effect-mainly or wholly absorbed
It is intended specifically for use in direct contact with the heart, central circulatory system or central nervous system
It is intended specifically to control, diagnose monitor and/or correct a defect, the heart or central circulatory system through direct contact
The device is surgically invasive for transient use, but none of these additional criteria apply

decision: (g). Which of the following applies to your device?
information: Wholly or mainly absorbed: ‘absorption’ in the context of implantable devices refers to the degradation of a material within the body and the metabolic elimination of the resulting degradation products from the body. It does not apply to those substances that are excreted without modification from the body, e.g. insufflation gases for the abdominal cavity or laparoscopic and endoscopic procedures.

options.when: It is intended to undergo a chemical change in the body (not in the teeth)
It is intended to administer medicines (not in the teeth)
It is intended to supply energy/ionizing radiation
It has a biological effect-mainly or wholly absorbed
It is intended specifically to monitor, control, diagnose or correct defects of the heart or central circulatory system by direct contact
It is intended for use in direct contact with the central nervous system, the heart or the central circulatory system
The device is surgically invasive for short term use, but none of these additional criteria apply

decision: (g). Which of the following applies to your device?
information: Wholly or mainly absorbed: ‘absorption’ in the context of implantable devices refers to the degradation of a material within the body and the metabolic elimination of the resulting degradation products from the body. It does not apply to those substances that are excreted without modification from the body, e.g. insufflation gases for the abdominal cavity or laparoscopic and endoscopic procedures.

options.when: It is intended to be placed in the teeth

decision: (h). Is it a component, such as a screw, wedge plate or instrument?

options.when: Yes
No

decision: Is it an active medical device?
hint:
Software is considered an active device. Medical devices using prestored gases and/or vacuum as a power source are also generally considered an active device if they meet the criteria in definition (detailed in the 'i' symbol). Devices that achieve their purpose through filtration and centrifugation (e.g., a hemodialyzer) are not considered active devices as they work exclusively through mechanical methods.

If your device is intended for channeling or storing blood, body liquids, cells or tissues, liquids or gases for the eventual purpose of infusion, administration or introduction into the body please select "No" to this question, as these devices are addressed later in the questionnaire. An example of this type of device is a fridge/freezer for storing blood and tissues.
information: Active medical device: Any device where the operation depends on a source of energy other than that generated by the human body for that purpose, or by gravity, and which acts by changing the density of or converting that energy. Devices intended to transmit energy, substances or other elements between an active device and the patient, without any significant change, are not considered active devices.

options.when: Yes
No

decision: (a). Which of the following applies to your device?
hint: If the product is a medical device software (MDSW), that does not mean that the software rule (Rule 11) automatically applies. Rules 9-13, 15 and 22 can all apply to software devices. Therefore, if you have a software device, we strongly recommend reviewing the guidance on medical device software classification (MDCG 2019-11) to best ensure the correct rule is selected. The strictest rule or sub-rule will apply.
information: Before proceeding with the next set of questions, please confirm that rule 22 does not apply to your device. If this rule applies, please review your response to question four. Rule 22: active therapeutic devices with an integrated or incorporated diagnostic function which significantly determines the patient management by the device, such as closed loop systems or automated external defibrillators.

options.when: It is a therapeutic device intended to administer or exchange energy
It is intended to diagnose and monitor or supply energy absorbed by the body or allow direct diagnosis or monitoring of vital physiological processes
It is intended to image in vivo distribution of radiopharmaceuticals
It is a software device
It is intended to administer and/or remove medicines and other substances from the body
It is an active device, but none of these other criteria apply

decision: (b). Which of the following applies to your device?
information: According to MDCG 2021-24, the determination of if a device administers or exchanges energy to and from the human body in a potentially hazardous way is based on the type of technology involved and the intended application of the device to the patient. It is not based on the measures adopted by the manufacturer, e.g., use of technical standards, risk analysis. For example, all devices intended to emit ionizing radiation and all lung ventilators are considered to administer energy in a potentially hazardous way.

options.when: It is intended to directly control, monitor or influence the performance of a class IIb active therapeutic device
It administers or exchanges energy in a potentially hazardous way
It is intended to emit ionizing radiation for therapeutic purposes, or it controls, monitors or directly influences the performance of devices that emit ionizing radiation for therapeutic purposes
It is intended for controlling, monitoring or directly influencing the performance of active implantable devices
None of these options apply to my device

options.when: It is intended to illuminate the patient's body, in the visible spectrum
It emits ionizing radiation for diagnostic or therapeutic radiology, including interventional radiology devices and devices which control or monitor such devices
It is specifically intended to monitor vital physiological parameters where variations could result in immediate danger to patient
It is intended for diagnosis in clinical situations where the patient is in immediate danger
None of these options apply to my device

decision: (c). Which of the following applies to your device?
information: An example of a device where the decision's impact may cause 'death or irreversible deterioration of health' is a device intended to make treatment decisions in patients with acute stroke. An example of a device where the decision's impact may cause 'serious deterioration in health or surgical intervention' is a mobile app intended to analyze a user’s heartbeat, detect abnormalities and inform a physician accordingly.

options.when: The decision's impact can cause serious deterioration in health or surgical intervention
The decision's impact can cause death or irreversible deterioration of health
Neither of these options apply to my device

decision: (d). Is it intended to monitor vital physiological parameters, where the nature of parameter variations could result in immediate danger to the patient?

options.when: Yes
No

decision: (b). Is the administration or removal of medicines or other substances from the body executed in a potentially hazardous way?
information: Whether it is executed in a potentially hazardous way should take into account of the nature of the substances involved, of the part of the body concerned and of the mode of application.

options.when: Yes
No

decision: The device is non-invasive and non-active - which of the following applies to your device?
information: Before proceeding with the next set of questions, please confirm that neither rule 14 nor rule 22 applies to your device. If one of these rules apply, please review your responses to questions one and four. Rule 14: devices incorporating integral medicinal substance and that has an action ancillary to that of the devices. Rule 22: active therapeutic devices with an integrated or incorporated diagnostic function which significantly determines the patient management by the device, such as closed loop systems or automated external defibrillators.
